page.topic: Using Xbasic to Read and Write to a Table
page.description: The new Alpha Anywhere developer eventually comes to the point where he or she would like to write a script that directly reads from and writes to a table. This topic provides a couple of simple examples that you can elaborate upon. The are based on the Customer table in the AlphaSports sample database.

section.title: Script or Function?
section.description: Perhaps the first question you will ask is: "Should this be a script or a function?". There is little difference in the Xbasic coding between the two alternatives. The determining issue is whether you want to return a value. Functions can return values. Scripts cannot return values, except by setting the value(s) of global variable(s), and this is often considered a sloppy and potentially troublesome programming practice.

section.title: How Do I Call a Script or Function?
section.description: Calling a function is as easy as naming it and catching the return value, if any. This example returns a value from the find_last_name() function:
section.example: dim return_value as C ... some code return_value = find_last_name() ... some code

section.description: Or, if the find_last_name() function required a parameter, you might write something like this:
section.example: dim return_value as C ... some code return_value = find_last_name("Michael") ... some code

section.description: If the find_last_name() function did not return a value, the syntax would simply be:
section.example: ... some code find_last_name() ... some code

section.description: Calling a script named find_first_name is just as easy:
section.example: ... some code script_play("find_first_name") ... some code
section.note: Function names always have parentheses in their names. Scripts do not.

section.title: Sequencing Through the Records of a Table
section.description: The following is the beginning of a script that reads and writes to the customer table. This script does not require that the customer table be open in a layout. First, create a table object named tbl (any variable name that is not a reserved word will do).
section.example: dim tbl as P tbl = table.open("customer")

section.description: Now read the first record.
section.example: tbl.fetch_first() while .not. table.fetch_eof() ' ... do something tbl.fetch_next() end while tbl.close()

section.description: Keep reading until you reach the end of the file.
section.example: tbl.fetch_first() while .not. table.fetch_eof() ' ... do something tbl.fetch_next() end while

section.description: Now, close the table.
section.example: tbl.close()

section.title: Reading a Field Value
section.description: Reading a field value is as simple as referencing table_object.field_name. In the following script the variable ln always contains the value of the lastname field in the current record:
section.example: dim tbl as P dim ln as C tbl = table.open("customer") tbl.fetch_first() while .not. table.fetch_eof() ln = tbl.lastname tbl.fetch_next() end while tbl.close()

section.title: Writing a Field Value
section.description: Writing a changed field value in a record requires two more statements. Suppose you wanted to make sure that the lastname field had an initial capital letter.
section.example: dim tbl as P dim ln as C tbl = table.open("customer") tbl.fetch_first() while .not. table.fetch_eof()

section.description: The tbl.change_begin(.t.) statement says that you are changing an existing field and that you want to honor any existing field rules.
section.example: tbl.change_begin(.t.) tbl.lastname = f_upper(tbl.lastname)

section.description: The tbl.change_end(.t.) statement says that you are finished changing an existing field and want to save the changes.
section.example: tbl.change_end(.t.) tbl.fetch_next() end while tbl.close()

section.title: Deleting a Record
section.description: The process of deleting a record is similar to changing a record. First, you need to use one of many techniques for finding the record you are going to delete.
section.example: dim tbl as P dim ln as C tbl = table.open("customer") tbl.fetch_first() while .not. table.fetch_eof()

section.description: This script tests the values of the firstname and lastname fields, and only deletes specific records.
section.example: if (tbl.lastname = "Smith") .and. (tbl.firstname = "John") then tbl.change_begin(.t.) tbl.delete()

section.description: The tbl.change_end(.t.) statement says that you are want to delete the record.
section.example: tbl.change_end(.t.) end if tbl.fetch_next() end while tbl.close()

section.title: Adding a Record
section.description: Adding a record is simple. You bracket your field updates with the tbl.enter_begin() and tbl.enter_end() statements.
section.example: dim tbl as P tbl = table.open("customer") tbl.enter_begin()

section.description: The tbl.enter_begin(.t.) statement says that you are adding a existing field to the end of the table and that you want to honor any existing field rules.
section.example: tbl.firstname = "George" tbl.lastname = "Washington"

section.description: The tbl.enter_end(.t.) statement says that you are finished adding a record and want to save the changes.
section.example: tbl.enter_end(.t.) tbl.close()

section.title: Selecting a Subset of Records with a Query
section.description: In each of the examples above, the code opened the customer table and sequenced through all of its records. Suppose you wanted only to sequence through the records when the bill_state_region field contained the value "MA". Instead of writing this code at the beginning of the script:
section.example: dim tbl as P tbl = table.open("customer")

section.description: you would write:
section.example: dim tbl as P dim qry as P tbl = table.open("customer") query.filter = "bill_state_region = 'MA'" qry = tbl.query_create() ... add, change, or delete ...

section.description: Finish the script or function by detaching the query and closing the table.
section.example: tbl.query_detach() tbl.close()

section.description: Now, you will sequence through only those customers in the state of Massachusetts.
